Award.AwardTitle: WiFiUS: Collaborative Research: Future Small-Cell Networks Using Reconfigurable Antennas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The future proliferation of wireless systems and services is dependent on the design of flexible radio architectures that can adapt to the rapidly changing wireless environment. Since usable spectrum is limited, and modulation and coding techniques are approaching their Shannon capacity limitation, improving capacity through increased spectrum reuse and interference mitigation has become a high priority in future cellular networks. Industry leaders have focused on a multi-tiered heterogeneous network structure, where small-cell (e.g., pico-cell, femto-cell) base stations are deployed to meet capacity demand. Among the technical challenges making full-scale deployment of small-cell base stations possible, interference management still looms the largest. This project focuses on providing wireless systems with the available hardware and algorithmic tools to make intelligent decisions about antenna configuration for small-cell base stations to mitigate interference and improve network capacity and coexistence in a heterogeneous network environment.

This project is composed of three main research thrusts: i.) Algorithm and System Design; ii.) Antenna and Transceiver Design; and iii.) Testbed Implementation. The first focus is on the mathematical modeling and overall system design of small-cell networks making use of reconfigurable antennas. A vital component of this overall system design is the development of efficient and effective analytical tools and algorithms for downlink transmission, focusing on directional network design, algorithms for directionality selection, and base station user association. The second thrust includes the development of practical reconfigurable antennas and transceiver processing techniques for small-cell base stations. The project team is adapting reconfigurable metamaterial and alford loop antenna designs to provide new, compact reconfigurable antenna architectures with both beam steering and variable beam width capabilities. Using these new antenna technologies this research enhances direction of arrival and digital pre-distortion techniques for enhanced small-cell uplink and downlink. The cornerstone of this research is the design of a fully implemented, programmable across-the-stack SDR platform with integrated reconfigurable antennas. This project makes use of open-source technologies and will result in the deployment of a fully functional cellular backbone system, consisting of both macro-cell and small-cell base stations.

This project leverages collaboration between Drexel University and WPI, along with a strong international collaboration with the University of Oulu, VTT Technical Research Centre and Tampere University of Technology. This ongoing collaboration with Finnish institutions continues to provide novel international research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students as well as pilot testing for dissemination of the developed testbed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The future proliferation of wireless systems and services is dependent on the design of flexible radio architectures that can adapt to the rapidly changing wireless environment. Since usable spectrum is limited, and modulation and coding techniques are approaching their Shannon capacity limitation, improving capacity through increased spectrum reuse and interference mitigation has become a high priority in future cellular networks. Industry leaders have focused on a multi-tiered heterogeneous network structure, where small-cell (e.g., pico-cell, femto-cell) base stations are deployed to meet capacity demand. Among the technical challenges making full-scale deployment of small-cell base stations possible, interference management still looms the largest. Reconfigurable antennas are antennas whose radiation characteristics can be adapted in response to the needs of the overlying small-cellular system. In this study, the project team demonstrated how deployment of reconfigurable antenna systems in small-cell base stations can improve cellular network capacity by mitigating interference and allowing for densification of mobile users in a given spatial deployment.

The project was approached in three main areas: algorithm and system design, reconfigurable antennas, and testbed implementation. The project team collaborated with their Finnish counterparts to work towards a successful solution. Through this collaboration, the team developed a scheme that synchronizes enterprise level WiFi networks (i.e. distributed over a large area) to a sub-microsecond accuracy. This accuracy allowed for implementation of LinkPursuit, which is a novel learning protocol for distributed antenna state selection in directional small-cell networks. Through the use of LinkPursit, leveraging the directionality of reconfigurable antennas, the project team was able to demonstrate increased throughput for a given wireless network even in the presence of an interfering network using the same space and frequency. Without the availability of LinkPursuit, this scenario would have been the victim of collisions that would have slowed down the network speed. For optimized performance, a Reconfigurable Alford Loop Antenna (RALA) was also developed in-house. RALA allows switching between traditional omni-directional mode, which is ideal for network discovery, and directional patterns that are separated by 90- and 45-degree alignments, which is used for directional transmissions to limit interference. The antenna is adopted by other projects within Drexel Wireless Systems Lab as well. Finally, the project team was able to implement the above algorithm on WARP software-define radio platform and integrate the reconfigurable antennas. Some aspects of the design, such as antenna mode selection control, were implemented directly on the FPGA to ensure minimum delay. The final product of the project enabled a platform for researchers that would like to perform wireless measurements that need synchronization and rapid switching of antenna modes and/or other user peripherals.

In addition to the intellectual merit demonstrated throughout the project, the project also had broader impacts in several areas. First, a strong bond between US and Finnish academic institutions was formed. The project facilitated many student exchanges between the two countries. The project team continued to collaborate with their Finnish colleagues even after the completion of this project. Furthermore, undergraduate students were mentored by the PI during the project, where an augmented reality mobile application (app) was developed and made available via app stores. This app was used to visualize wireless links, sent/received packets and antenna radiation patterns by pointing one’s smartphone towards a wireless access point—not visible to human eye normally. This demo was used for outreach purposes at open houses and lab tours for high school students and current undergraduate student to raise interest for Engineering. Finally, a sequence of courses was offered studying cognitive radio that were partially supported by this project. A mix of undergraduate and graduate students were enrolled in the sequence. Out of the 14 students enrolled in the sequence, 4 of them continued their work in this area as independent study after the competition of the course sequence. Overall, the project was completed with no diversions from the originally proposed scope.
